answers.answer: Your doc should refer you to an endocrinologist who specializes in Thyroid, not diabetes. Many auto-immune conditions can run together. It is not uncommon for a person wtih Lupus to have Hashimoto's Disease.People with Hashimoto's (which causes HYPO-thyroidism) have high TSH. You should have your Hashi antibodies tested (TGab and TPOab). Also, I suggest getting Vitamin D levels tested. I'm a Hashi who has difficulty maintaining vitamin D.D vitamin is needed for calcium absorbtion, strong bones.Again, a good endo will know better how to treat and diagnose you. TSH is not as important as the freeT3/freeT4 levels, which tell us directly what the thryoid is doing. TSH is a pituitary hormone.:) Tamra

question: When I was first diagnosed with thyroid problems my TSH was over 250!  I sounded like I was drunk all the time, my speach was so slurred, my memory was seriously effected, and I lost half of my hair!  My GP finally had me tested after about a year of this tourture!  I'm not too sure if this too contributed to the cause of how BOTH my legs were broken (not al the same time but 6 months apart!)  these breaks weren't from a serious fall but a slight slip, most people wouldn't have even suffered a sprained ankle!  Anyhow, my main question is, is this Hyperthyroid, Hypothyroid,could there be another issue I should be watching for?  I also suffer from Lupus, and most recently had blood work done showing a problem with my Liver.  My Gamma GT levels are high at 57.  If you can help please fill me in?
title: Hypo vs Hyper?
